definition: Departing from an accepted standard; deviant
Clear, logical, and convincing
Lasting for a very short time
Fond of the company of others; sociable
Expressed clearly; easy to understand
Dealing with things sensibly and realistically
Using or expressed in more words than are needed
Departing from an accepted standard; deviant
example: The aberrant behavior of the student concerned the teachers.

definition: Clear, logical, and convincing
example: She presented a cogent argument for the new policy.

definition: Lasting for a very short time
example: The beauty of cherry blossoms is ephemeral.

definition: Fond of the company of others; sociable
example: His gregarious nature made him popular at parties.

definition: Expressed clearly; easy to understand
example: The professor gave a lucid explanation of the complex theory.

definition: Dealing with things sensibly and realistically
example: She took a pragmatic approach to solving the problem.

definition: Using more words than necessary
example: His verbose speech bored the audience.

definition: To make something better or more tolerable
example: Measures were taken to ameliorate the living conditions.

definition: Open to more than one interpretation; unclear
example: The instruction was ambiguous and caused confusion.

definition: Something that deviates from the norm; irregularity
example: The sudden drop in sales was an anomaly for the company.

definition: Very enthusiastic or passionate
example: He is an ardent supporter of the team.

definition: Severe or strict in manner or appearance; simple
example: The monastery had an austere lifestyle.

definition: Well meaning and kindly
example: The benevolent donor funded the school building.

definition: Hostile and aggressive
example: The belligerent tone of the speaker alarmed the audience.

definition: Truthful and straightforward; frank
example: She gave a candid assessment of the situation.

definition: Kept secret or done secretly
example: They held clandestine meetings after hours.

definition: Giving a lot of information clearly in few words
example: Keep your answers concise in the exam.

definition: A confusing and difficult problem or question
example: The puzzle presented a real conundrum.

definition: To confirm or give support to (a statement, theory, or finding)
example: The witness corroborated the defendant's alibi.

definition: Having or showing too great a readiness to believe things
example: Credulous people often fall for scams.

definition: Hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed
example: He gave the report only a cursory glance.

definition: Causing harm or damage
example: Smoking has deleterious effects on health.

definition: Reserved, modest, and shy
example: Her demure behavior suited the formal event.

definition: To express contempt for; ridicule
example: They derided his suggestion as impractical.

definition: Showing care and conscientiousness in one's work or duties
example: A diligent student studies daily.

definition: A lack of compatibility or similarity between two or more facts
example: There was a discrepancy between the accounts.

definition: To spread or disperse widely (information, ideas)
example: The organization disseminated the new guidelines to all staff.

definition: Hesitating or doubting; not to be relied upon
example: He was dubious about the claim.

definition: To draw out (a response, answer, or fact) from someone
example: The question elicited a thoughtful reply.

definition: Fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing
example: Her speech was eloquent and moving.

definition: A person or thing that is mysterious or difficult to understand
example: The origins of the artifact remain an enigma.

definition: To destroy completely; put an end to
example: Efforts were made to eradicate the disease.

definition: Intended for or understood by only a small group of people
example: The text contained esoteric philosophical ideas.

definition: To make a problem or negative feeling worse
example: His comments only exacerbated the tension.

definition: To clear someone of blame or wrongdoing
example: The evidence served to exonerate the accused.

definition: Based on a mistaken belief; logically unsound
example: That argument is fallacious and cannot be accepted.

definition: Having or displaying a passionate intensity
example: She was a fervent advocate for education reform.

definition: Happening by accident or chance; fortunate
example: It was fortuitous that he found the lost document.

definition: Sparing or economical regarding money or food
example: They lived a frugal lifestyle to save for the future.

definition: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters
example: The garrulous guide spoke non-stop.

definition: Lacking any obvious principle of organization; random
example: The files were arranged in a haphazard way.

definition: Excessive pride or self-confidence
example: His hubris led to poor decisions.

definition: Acting quickly and without thought or care; impulsive
example: An impetuous decision cost them dearly.

definition: Implied though not plainly expressed; tacit
example: There was implicit trust between the partners.

definition: Not showing proper respect; rude
example: His impertinent remark annoyed the teacher.

definition: In accordance with the highest standards; faultless
example: Her performance was impeccable.

definition: A hindrance or obstruction in doing something
example: Poor infrastructure is an impediment to growth.

definition: Not in harmony or keeping with the surroundings; inappropriate
example: His jokes seemed incongruous at the solemn event.

definition: Originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native
example: These plant species are indigenous to the region.

definition: Inborn; natural
example: She had an innate sense of direction.

definition: Proceeding in a gradual, subtle way but with harmful effects
example: Insidious disease progression made diagnosis difficult.

definition: Necessary to make a whole complete; essential
example: Trust is integral to a good partnership.

definition: Temporary and intended to be used or accepted until something permanent exists
example: An interim report was published before the final one.

definition: Using or based on what one feels to be true without conscious reasoning
example: Her intuitive choice proved correct.

definition: To overwhelm (someone) with things or people to be dealt with; flood
example: The office was inundated with applications.

definition: Using words to convey a meaning that is the opposite of its literal meaning; unexpected in a striking way
example: It was ironic that the fire station burned down.

definition: Having, showing, or done with good judgment or sense
example: A judicious use of resources is required.

definition: Using very few words; concise to the point of seeming rude or mysterious
example: His laconic reply ended the discussion.

definition: Deserving praise and commendation
example: Her efforts to help the community were laudable.

definition: Affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic
example: After the long flight he felt lethargic.

definition: Very generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or someone less powerful
example: He was magnanimous in victory.

definition: Having or showing a wish to do evil to others
example: The plot was driven by a malevolent villain.

definition: To make less severe, serious, or painful
example: Measures were taken to mitigate the impact of the storm.

definition: Lacking interest or excitement; dull; of this earthly world rather than a heavenly one
example: He longed to escape his mundane routine.

definition: Wicked or criminal
example: The organization was involved in nefarious activities.

definition: So small or unimportant as to be not worth considering; insignificant
example: The cost was negligible compared to the benefit.

definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action
example: Despite pleas, he remained obdurate.

definition: Not discovered or known about; uncertain; not clearly expressed or easily understood
example: The reference was obscure and hard to trace.

definition: Out of date; no longer in use or useful
example: The technology quickly became obsolete.

definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or chosen course of action
example: He was obstinate and would not listen to advice.

definition: Involving a great deal of effort, difficulty, or responsibility; burdensome
example: The new regulations imposed an onerous burden on small businesses.

definition: Conforming to what is generally or traditionally accepted as right or true; conventional
example: He took a more orthodox approach to the problem.

definition: Characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress
example: Her ostentatious jewelry attracted attention.

definition: A statement that contradicts itself or a situation that seems to defy logic yet may be true
example: The paradox of thrift describes saving that harms the economy.

definition: Strongly supporting a particular party, cause, or person; biased
example: The report was criticized as being partisan.

definition: The presence of something only in small or insufficient quantities; scarcity
example: There is a paucity of reliable data.

definition: Lasting or existing for a long or apparently infinite time; enduring
example: He faced the perennial problem of funding.

definition: Carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection; superficial
example: She gave a perfunctory nod and left.

definition: Not securely held or in position; dangerously likely to fall or collapse; uncertain
example: The hikers were in a precarious position on the cliff edge.

definition: Having developed certain abilities or proclivities at an earlier age than usual
example: A precocious child can astonish adults with early talents.

definition: Failing to observe the limits of what is permitted or appropriate; overconfident
example: It was presumptuous of him to assume the role.

definition: Widespread in a particular area or at a particular time
example: That idea is prevalent among the youth.

definition: Delay or postpone action; put off doing something
example: Don't procrastinateâ€”start revising today.

definition: Commonplace; unromantic; lacking poetic beauty
example: The account was prosaic and failed to inspire.

definition: Producing much fruit or foliage or many offspring; highly productive
example: The author was prolific, producing many novels.

definition: Acting with or showing care and thought for the future; wise
example: It is prudent to save a portion of your income.

definition: Put an end to (a rebellion or other disorder), typically by the use of force; suppress
example: Authorities moved to quell the unrest.

definition: Representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class
example: He is the quintessential professional: punctual and prepared.

definition: Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude toward authority or discipline
example: The recalcitrant student refused to follow instructions.

definition: Restore friendly relations between; make (one thing) compatible with another
example: They managed to reconcile their differences.
